item.title: Installing a payphone in my house
item.description: When I was growing up in the 90s, I remember wanting to get on the Internet. My parents weren’t going to help me, so I called up an ISP and said I wanted to set up an account. They asked for my name and I gave them a fake name. And then they asked for a credit card number and I told them I had to find my wallet and call them back.

item.title: Ceiling Air Purifier
item.description: Imagine a high-capacity air filter that is extremely quiet and doesn't get in the way. I think I see how to build one; here's a prototype: By putting a fan on the ceiling you can have very long blades. This is important for keeping noise down: the longer your blades are the more air you move at a given rotational velocity, which is a major determinant of noise. Testing my prototype, it has a
item.author: (Jeff Kaufman)

item.title: Comparing Exceptions and Errors in D
item.description: What are Exceptions and Errors in D? Why is there a difference? Why does D consider Errors throwable inside a nothrow function? Sometimes decisions seem arbitrary, but when you finally understand the reasoning, you can better appreciate why things are the way they are.

item.title: How fast are Linux pipes anyway?
item.description: Pipes are ubiquitous in Unix --- but how fast can they go on Linux? In this post we'll iteratively improve a simple pipe-writing benchmark from 3.5GiB/s to 65GiB/s, guided by Linux `perf`.

item.title: Is an ANEMIC Domain Model really that BAD?
item.description: Is an anemic domain model a bad thing? Most would probably call it an anti-pattern, and it should be avoided. But is that really true?
